title: Wednesday, 1st August, 2018
bodyHTML:
Excel Developer hi
11:08 am
BE11:08am

It's August!

BE11:08am

The Most Wonderful Time Of The Year.

Excel Developer @BE: what happens on August 20th?
Blank canvas good morning everyone
DRichi Isn't Christmas the most wonderful time of the year?
Soundbuy Morning
AAAA salut !
BE11:09am

When we get our annual fortnight to go to Blackpool and play the ha'penny shove on the pier.

Tax Realist Any chat on the Elementis announcement yesterday?
11:09 am
BE11:09am

That's still a while off yet though. And luckily, there's news to keep us going.

BE11:10am

Starting with this: https://ftalphavil...-secret-pay-deal-/

BE11:10am

Conservative MP Grant Shapps has resigned from two appointments related to blockchain technology, after FT Alphaville discovered a secret pay deal with a company run by a civil servant that had promoted itself through an event it said would be held in the Houses of Parliament.

Shapps, a former chair of the Conservative party until his resignation amid a 2015 bullying scandal, had been due to receive cryptocurrency tokens expected to be worth hundreds of thousands of pounds for his role advising the blockchain startup OpenBrix, ahead of a sale of tokens to the public, in what is known as an initial coin offering (ICO).

11:10 am
BE11:10am

You remember Mr Shapps, right?

BE11:11am

You might remember him as Michael Green.

DRichi or Sebastian Fix/Fox too no?
BE11:13am

I wonder what about blockchain attracted this modestly trustworthy individual with a history of trying to sell get-rich-quick schemes?

Patience @BE - hoist by his own fake petard :-)
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Anyway, great story from Jemima. Go read it rather than me.

JimboRock DLG please, if you get time
undefined
chopper bear anythign on man group please
BE11:14am

Okay, so we begin. And Direct Line seems as good a place as any.

11:14 am
Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 331.20, down 12.7 (-3.69%), High: 346.90, Low: 327.80, Volume: 3.45m
BE11:14am

The headline news is that the CEO's off, after ten years.

Soundbuy Smurfit - any grey appreciated..........
BE11:15am

Though it's a one-year succession plan so you have to assume that it's all orderly and voluntary.

MassimoJ Thoughts on Capita?
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Against that, you have pretty amazing first-half numbers ..... 25% ahead of consensus on the operating profit line.

BE11:16am

.......... However.

BE11:16am

It's mostly reserve releases and lower commissions.

Manxish Morning each
11:17 am
BE11:17am

The more interesting news is that claims inflation has returned, which echoes what Sabre reported yesterday.

BE11:18am

Sabre Insurance was the reason all the car insurers went up 3-5% yesterday, because they said they'd be passing on claims inflation with higher rates.

TheRoman753 Morning
BE11:18am

Direct Line's message isn't quite so certain.

Pseudonym God moaning.
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Market still rational but competition no less aggressive. That kind of thing.

hedgehog Aggreko pls
Pseudonym LLoyds still looks undervalued to me, presumably some people are expecting it to implode somehow?
BE11:19am

Here's Goldman to wrap it all together.

BE11:19am

Overall, we see this as a moderate beat on an underlying basis and we
note that market trends, albeit still supportive, appear to have normalised
somewhat. In combination with the announced leadership change, we expect the earnings release to result in a muted share price response today.

nichoman Great story / scoop. Mind you, a friend of mine did a deal with a tech company that promised him tokens....the promised ICO keeps getting delayed and the thousands of $ he's hoping for in tokens may be worthless
11:19 am
BE11:20am

DLG’s 1H18 operating profit of £303mn is 24% ahead of company-compiled consensus (£245mn) largely driven by: (i) a significant
improvement in the commission ratio (6.5% vs. consensus of 8.4%); (ii) strong prior-year reserve releases of £207mn (vs. consensus of £169mn), mainly due to benign large bodily injury claims; and (iii) higher-than-expected instalment/other income (£99mn vs. consensus of £88mn).

BE11:20am

Underlying slightly ahead: However, roughly half of the beat on the
commission ratio relates to lower profit sharing with partners and
installment/other includes a £10mn gain on property. Adjusting for this and above-trend reserve releases, we estimate underlying operating earnings of £250-260mn, which puts the numbers 2%-6% ahead of consensus. We note also that some key items, such as the current year attritional, the expense ratio and premiums were weaker than expected, which may be taken negatively. Full-year guidance was reiterated.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:22am

So .. you have claims inflation returning to the long-term trend 3%-5% levels and a slowdown in rate momentum in the first half .... suggesting the windfall period for UK car insurance might be coming to an end.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Citi:

BE11:22am

24% operating profit beat versus consensus was driven by PYD and one-offs. Looking through these items, the results appear broadly in-line but with some sign of greater competition in motor (own brand policy growth was negligible in Q2 vs Q1 and claims inflation is reverting to normal). The CEO will be leaving in the summer of 2019, which we view as a negative, but there is a long transition period and this should see him implement the long awaited new policy administration systems that should prove a key legacy.

Bonnemort You can see why Cameron and Shapps were so close
BE11:24am

Good note from Caz last week talking about switching to European car insurers to ride the "reserve releases from benign claims inflation and cartel pricing" thing: https://www.ft.com...-bb8f-a6a2f7bca546

OnYourRight Morning all
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Makes the reasonable argument that, because the UK has more developed price comparison sites, pricing's likely to fall quicker to match claims rates than on the Continent.

undefined
Bonnemort Do Euro insurers have crash for cash and whiplash claims?
BE11:26am

On Elementis, which we didn't mention yesterday due to the earnings bombardment .....

11:27 am
BE11:27am

.... and the slightly leftfield news that management is reconsidering its options on the Mondo transaction.

BE11:28am

Apparently in response to shareholder pushback, so not entirely clear why the market read it as a negative.

Elementis PLC (ELM:LSE): Last: 260.20, no change, High: 263.20, Low: 258.40, Volume: 134.46k
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Here's Credit Suisse's guess at what's happening.

Soundbuy ELM - mkt seemed to like the news at the open............then slowly early gains eroded...
BE11:29am

The board is looking at options surrounding the
Mondo transaction, we believe these are 1) Negotiating a lower price – we
estimate less than $500m and the deal begins to look value accretive on more than 12x EBITDA, less than 5% FCF yield, more than 1% EPS accretive ex synergies AND less than 9.5x EBITDA, less than 6.6% FCF yield, less than 8% EPS accretive including cost/revenue synergies of $10mn, 2) cancelling the deal and refocusing Management's efforts on the second option – the break fee is $18mn or ~1% of the market cap. We believe the market would view both alternatives as a net positive (relative to the original transaction).

OnYourRight I am so bored today...... almost no point in working this week. Only interesting thing is that a spread betting account has been suspended due to new margin call requirements...haha
undefined
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Man Group? Guess so.

Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 182.90, up 9.4 (+5.42%), High: 185.20, Low: 171.10, Volume: 3.66m
BE11:31am

H1's as expected. In line, though flows are slightly better than consensus.

SB from VB @ BE - Good morning, any colour on Rio Tinto pls?
11:31 am
BE11:32am

The main positive seems to be a higher quality mix.

BE11:33am

$3.5bn against a consensus at $2.6bn and, if you add that to Q1, probably a record first half in terms of cash gathering.

BE11:34am

Morgan Stanley does a nice earnings scorecard thing for the asset managers that saves you reading anything longer than three words. It's good.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

BE11:34am

Course, the thing with Man Group is that it's been dead money approximately forever.

BE11:35am

Attempts to diversify and break the link with the AHL franchise -- partly to my mind by hiding the performance data -- seems not to have done an awful lot.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Numis is neutral.

BE11:36am

There remain many short to medium-term uncertainties at Man,
including inconsistent performance/performance fees, volatile flows and significant fee margin pressure. We think the short to medium-term outlook for the current business is for modest growth, in terms of the direction of management fee profits. Upside could come from the surplus capital (c.11p/share currently plus the extent of future performance fee profits), which could be distributed and/or used for M&A (provided it is value accretive). We think M&A is more likely than capital returns.

ad next?
ad off 7% on good news?
Alex1621 Next plc ... do exceptionally hot summers drive sales, or reduce store foot fall as people find more entertaining things to do in the hot weather? Next plc looked reassuring, any thoughts?
BE11:38am

Remember that joke we used to do about how AHL's most profitable strategy would be to short Man shares ... though I'm not sure how that would work longer term.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

The profit gained by shorting Man would boost AHL which would boost Man and reverse AHL's performance, which would sink Man, which would boost AHL and ........

BE11:39am

...... it'd be like fund management designed by MC Escher.

BE11:39am

Anyway.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:39am

Next.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 5,500, down 436 (-7.35%), High: 5,632, Low: 5,496, Volume: 666.86k
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Simple enough story really.

Soundbuy @Alex1621 - Shopping = Recreation, Recreation = Shopping nowadays........
BE11:39am

Market was anticipating the sales beat.

Excel Developer @BE: that would test Efficient Markets Hypothesis (MAN shorting MAN shares)
BE11:40am

Market was also anticipating an upgrade to full-year, which didn't happen.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Because management's saying sales have been pulled forward due to the warm weather.

Grouchmonkey @alex the Next statement referred to them shifting extra large amounts of lightweight summer clobber, I believe, so they think it’s a positive
Soundbuy Folks more willing to part with the readies when the sun's out.....
BE11:41am

So. Consensus doesn't change and shares reverse most of the 10% or so they did in the run-up to the numbers.

Soundbuy Some of us just drink more.............
BE11:41am

UBS can summarise what's been said.

JulioIgelsias Capita seemed an over-reaction today?
11:41 am
BE11:42am

The Q2 beat of +1.8% vs Next's +1% budget was driven by hot weather from late June onwards. The weather impact is evident in the outperformance of summer clothing, with a weaker performance by some indoor homewares categories. Strong full price sell through of summer clothing means 1) clearance rates were lower than anticipated and 2) some sales are likely to have been pulled forward from Q3. Despite a 5.7% tougher comp in Q2, Online strength persisted (+12.5% vs UBSe +12.5%, cons +12%), driven by overseas and Label. There should be more self-help from upcoming developments such as the new 3 step credit offer. Retail LFL was c.-6.5% (UBSe and cons -6.5%), for -5.9% total full price sales growth (UBSe -5.8%, cons -5.3%).

BE11:42am

Next has maintained full price sales (+2.2%) and PBT (£717m) guidance, which implies broadly flat H2 full price sales growth. We retain our FY Brand full price sales forecast of +2.4% and PBT of £725m. Better clearance rates in Q2 would have added c£4m to profit, however this was offset by higher warehouse and distribution costs. Next is starting to experience a similar trend to some online apparel retailers, with Unlimited customers ordering smaller baskets, transacting more frequently and returning more. The £300m buyback this year has now been completed.

BE11:43am

They're buyers on the last-man-standing theory.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

The medium term continues to look favourable for Next. 1) Self-help in Online should continue to deliver sales momentum, with new projects continuing throughout FY19 and beyond (3 step credit, AI search engine functionality, more personalisation) and 2) Capacity exit in the sector continues, freeing up market share (even though it may be too early to see the impact of M&S C&H closures). House of Fraser's CVA could also provide some benefit to Next via additional brands joining Label as opportunities to sell as third party brands in physical stores reduce.

Excel Developer Fed FOMC today, BofE tomorrow, BoJ a few days ago. Any macro Bryce?
BE11:44am

I'd suggest, entirely anecdotally, that Next's probably the main beneficiary from H&M suddenly turning into a giant jumble sale in a market stall warehouse.

sprout Hang on, that Man earning's scorecard thing - how can net flows be 'major positive' but AuM 'no surprise' ?
BE11:45am

It's still a bit of a mystery why H&M's come off the rails so badly. But you only have to go into one to know there are serious, serious problems. Which makes Stefan Persson's recent and regular purchases all the more intriguing.

Grouchmonkey @sprout also, if performance fees are down because performance is v ordinary why the inflows? Triumph of marketing over reality?
11:46 am
undefined
Phil Morning! Loved the Grant Schapps article. Leopards & spots sprang immediately to mind for some reason.
BE11:48am

(@Sprout etc: AuM was $113.7bn, which looks light of consensus, so I assume crappy fund performance has offset net inflows.)

sprout makes sense - thanks BE
BE11:48am

Couple of requests for Capita.

Soundbuy Smurfit SKG...........if I may?
11:48 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 149.95, down 12.05 (-7.44%), High: 160.95, Low: 141.80, Volume: 13.38m
sprout see, it did need more than three words to explain in the end though. performance must be awful if it offsets 'major positive' flows.
BE11:50am

Numbers in line at the headline and guidance unchanged, but that doesn't mean it's good news. Because it's Capita.

BE11:50am

Free cashflow isn't coming through.

Grouchmonkey Any comment on BAe please?
MassimoJ They'd flagged the FCF outflow though right, in their YE17/strategy update?
11:51 am
BE11:51am

And management still don't want to call stability. Plus, there's no divisional update.

BE11:52am

That's post Capita rejigging its structure a few months ago.

BE11:53am

All of which, along with the disposals and rather complicated definition of underlying earnings, make Capita numbers a rather frustrating read.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Here's Peel Hunt to summarise where we are.

BE11:53am

Underlying PBT down 59% to £80.5m. Underlying revenues declined by 5.4% (LFL down 2.3% including a 2.4% organic decline) due to limited new contract wins, customer contract attrition in Customer Management, IT & Networks and Government Services and the re-shaping of the DIO contract. EBITA down 53% (down 31% pre significant contracts and restructuring costs) as a consequence of the above and a decline in the Peoples Solution margin and the dropping out of the one-off supplier settlement in IT (margin 5.5%/7.9% pre significant contracts and restructuring costs vs 11.1%). On track to realise £70m of savings by 2018 and £175m by 2020. Balance sheet strengthened via £701m rights issue and £419m expected disposal proceeds (well ahead of £300m target). EPS down 50% to 6.96p.

BE11:54am

And here are the mechanical downgrades.

Excel Developer Should I sell Japan stocks? BoJ now owns 70% of equities ETFs. I wonder when they might sell them back into market?
11:54 am
BE11:54am

2018 underlying pre-tax profits [before significant new contracts & restructuring costs] guidance has been reduced from between £270 and £300m to between £250m and £275m to reflect the diposals of non-core businesses made year to date [principally ParkingEye and Supplier Assessment Services]. PH estimates have still to incorporate the July disposals. On this basis prior to discussions with management we anticipate reducing 2018E PBT by £14.0m (5%) from £275.2m (EPS 15.1p) to £261.2m (14.3p) and 2019E PBT by £14.0m (5%) from £296.6m (EPS 13.7p) to £282.5m (13.1p).

Alex1621 Next plc - exceptional summers keep people away from stores, that explains store sales dip in Q2 being greater than Q1. Argument that August sales b/f seems classic understatement from Woolfson, known to under promise and over deliver. We'll know at next update, that might see upgrade that was expected today.
BE11:55am

So -- 12 or 13 times 2019. Not startlingly cheap.

simple simon @BE i know you love banks...any grey on Lloyds please?
BE11:55am

Quick line from Jefferies.

Excel Developer Here is BoJ's ETF holdings https://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-09-11/wtf-chart-day-boj-now-owns-75-japanese-etfs
11:55 am
BE11:55am

We remain cautious regarding Capita’s recovery profile because, after an initial period of euphoria, outsourcers have taken longer than expected to extract savings and past reputational/performance/financial issues have weighed on revenue attrition.

undefined
cloudy Was there politics behind Royal Mail's agm vote, any one know?
BE11:56am

(@Excel: we did a bit on Japan yesterday in case it's useful.)

Excel Developer @BE: thanks for redirecting.
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Still on requests, I guess we need to to Lloyds.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 63.51, up 1.13 (+1.81%), High: 63.95, Low: 63.10, Volume: 97.60m
Patience @Excel Developer - re Japanese blue-chips, maybe. But don't see £ rising against yen. I like small Japanese company funds.
BE11:58am

Is Lloyds still the most-owned stock (directly speaking) among retail investors?

Excel Developer @Patience: yes I like Japan Smaller Cos too.
11:59 am
BE11:59am

So ...... Q2 beats slightly and there's a guidance upgrade.

BE12:00pm

Which might -- might! -- indicate a bigger cash return is on the way.

BE12:00pm

RBC can summarise the figures.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

LOY reported Q2 results 12% ahead of consensus at an underlying profit level with beats across most lines. LLOY has upgraded guidance for 2018 on NIM; capital generation; and costs. We rate LLOY Outperform, 90p price target trading on 8.3x 2019 P/E (adj).

BE12:01pm

LLOY reported NII up 6% yoy inline with consensus. Banking NIM of 2.93% in the quarter is resilient and slightly better than consensus at 2.92%. LLOY has upgraded guidance on NIM - previously c.2.9% for the year now H3 is expected to be inline with H1 (2.93%). Average interest earning banking assets increased 1% yoy (down 1% from end 2017).
Other income declined 8% yoy but 12% better than consensus leading to an income beat of 4%. LLOY expects other income to be inline with 2017 excluding Vocalink gains.
Costs are 2% lower yoy and 1% better than consensus. The cost-income ratio in the quarter was broadly flat on the previous quarter at 47.7%.
Impairments increased 40% yoy but are 31% better than consensus. Cost of risk guidance is upgraded from less than 30bps to less than 25bps now.
Capital generation is 121bps in H1 including 25bps from the sale of the Irish mortgage portfolio and a pre dividend capital ratio of 15.1%. LLOY increased their capital guidance to c.200bps this year pre dividend from 170-200bps. LLOY has provided upgraded pillar 2a guidance showing a reduction in pillar 2a from 3.0% to 2.7%.
There was an additional PPI charge in Q2 of £460m which now covers claims volumes of 13,000 a week until August 2019 compared to 11,000 previously.
Ordinary DPS increased to 1.07p from 1.0p in H1.

BE12:02pm

And Davy.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY)
continues to manage the net interest margin (NIM) well, as
evidenced by upgrades to c.2.93% (from 2.90%), and asset
quality remains ahead of expectations. Somewhat overshadowing
these positives were additional Q2 PPI charges and more general
concerns regarding the health of the UK economy.

taxloss Huge props to Jemima Kelly, corker
BE12:04pm

And Barclays.

BE12:04pm

Overall, underlying earnings are a 12% beat on stronger revenues - we’d expect focus on the sustainability of strong other operating income. The shares have been weak into results, but we’d expect price reaction to be firm today - and in particular note scope for a bigger FY18 buyback than consensus currently expects.

12% underlying PBT beat - Q2 underlying pre-tax profits of £2,230m are 12% ahead of consensus, driven by revenues 4% better and impairment 31% lower than consensus expectations (17bp charge), partly offset by expenses which are 3% heavy (due to higher remediation costs). Within income the beat comes from strong other operating income at £1,713m 12% better than expected (up 21% q/q, down 8% y/y) - which looks to be driven by better volumes in insurance, pensions, but does include some gilt sales and bulk annuity. Net interest income is exactly in line, flat q/q, with the NIM flat at 2.93% (they are guiding for FY18 NIM at 2.93% vs. cons at 2.92%). They’ve taken a £460m PPI top-up alongside £239m restructuring, driving stat PBT of £1,515, 6% light vs. consensus (up 5% q/q).

Capital/dividend/room for £2bn buybacks this year? CET1 ratio is flat q/q at 14.1% - guidance for FY18 capital build has been increased to 200bp (from 170-200bp). Interim dividend per share of 1.07p is up 7% q/q, and on a one-thirds to two-thirds split, indicates a FY18 dividend of 3.21p vs. consensus at 3.3p. Assuming the 200bp of capital generation is achieved as guided, this means £4.2bn of surplus capital generation this year, after dividend of £2.3bn (equiv to 3.21p per share), this would give room for £2bn share buyback vs. consensus £1bn. TNAV is flat q/q at 52.1p.

Reiterate our Overweight rating: seeing the shares attractively valued at 7.7x 2019e earnings, and 1.18x 2018e TNAV for a 15-16% underlying RoTE 2018-2020e.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Course, buying a bank ahead of BOE tomorrow would be a tad risky.

BE12:05pm

Your money though.

undefined
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

And, yeah, okay. Smurfit.

Excel Developer 10Yr JGB Yield has lost all BoJ jedi mind trick influence and blow out to 12bps https://www.zerohedge.com/sites/default/files/styles/inline_image_desktop/public/inline-images/10Yr JGB 8.1.jpg?itok=fQqiy5kv
Blank canvas thanks for everything today
BE12:06pm

H1 beats. Boxes, mostly, as well as costs. Outlook fine.

BE12:07pm

Here's Goodbody. Or, as we now have to call them, 好身材.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Smurfit Kappa has reported H118 EBITDA of €724m (+27% yoy) which is in line with our forecasts of and compares to our forecast of €722m and consensus €707m. There was some variance in the mix with a slightly weaker than expected outcome in Europe offset by a stronger result in the Americas. This implies that growth accelerated from +22% in Q118 to +32% in Q218. Of note to us is how this is translating into the eps growth of almost 70%, reflecting the benefit of lower finance charge. Overall this is a solid set of numbers from Smurfit Kappa we are likely to upgrade our forecast for the contribution from Reparenco in due course with our underlying assumptions remaining unchanged. We believe these results are going to be well received with upgrades to follow.

Excel Developer no unicode please.
BE12:08pm

In Europe, EBITDA has grown by 34% yoy to €587m which compares to our forecast of €595m. Corrugated volumes increased by 3% (lfl 2%) during the period while box pricing is up 7% (with a further c.2% to go) as management continue to recover the well documented increase in containerboard prices. Latin America also produced a strong set of results with EBITDA up 8% demonstrating a good recovery of input cost inflation. This reflects a 150bps increase in Americas margins which are expected to accelerate in H2.

BE12:08pm

( https://www.ft.com...-b747-fb1e803ee64e )

12:09 pm
undefined
Excel Developer cheers bye
BE12:11pm

That's us through time. Apologies for not covering Aggreko or BBA or Dignity or whatever else. I'll try to fix that shortly over here: https://www.ft.com/stocks-to-watch

Soundbuy Cheers all...........
BE12:11pm

Ta for sticking around. Back tomorrow.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Afternoon all.
